quizzes.question:
What is the value of y after this code runs?
x, y = [1, 2]
x, y = y, x
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Tuple Unpacking[/h1]

[b]Tuple unpacking[/b] allows you to assign each item in an iterable (often a tuple) to a variable.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="446"]numbers = (1, 2, 3)
[b]a, b, c = numbers[/b]
print(a)
print(b)
print(c)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
1
2
3
>>>[/code]
[note]This can be also used to swap variables by doing[b] a, b = b, a [/b], since[b] b, a[/b] on the right hand side forms the tuple[b] (b, a) [/b]which is then unpacked.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
a, b, c, d, *e, f, g = range(20)
print(len(e))
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Tuple Unpacking[/h1]

A variable that is prefaced with an asterisk (*) takes all values from the iterable that are left over from the other variables.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="447"]a, b, [b]*c[/b], d = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]
print(a)
print(b)
print(c)
print(d)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
1
2
[b][3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8][/b]
9
>>>[/code]
